Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Reconfigurable Textile Antennas and Radio Frequency (RF) Electronics Using Microfluidic Techniques

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to introduce and research game-changing approaches for reliable (a) reconfigurable RF front-ends using novel microfluidics that incorporates movable metal-coated quartz pieces within polymer channels to realize parasitic loadings, and (b) flexible electronics into attractive garments with performance similar to their inflexible copper counterparts. The proposed microfluidic reconfiguration concept has never been tried before, and is aimed at overcoming issues with previous microfluidic switching mechanisms that suffer from toxicity and oxidation. Its success is transformative as it will lead to reliable and non-toxic reconfigurations based on widely available materials.
The intellectual merit is to research novel microfluidic reconfiguration concepts. Because these concepts have never been considered before, there are challenges relating to their viability, requiring coexistence of several new technologies, including fluidic flow, fabrication of coated quartz particles/pieces, oxidation, fabrication of new channels using composite polymers, material compatibility, repeatability and reliability. The proposed devices are aimed at achieving reliable high speed connectivity, regardless of a person?s position or movement. The broader impact of the proposed reconfigurable textile antennas and RF front-ends is game-changing. It will enable efficient access to the entire radio spectrum and provide for on-demand remote medical monitoring of medical patients, allowing them to stay at home. The realization of this technology provides for a unique opportunity to carry out multidisciplinary research in material science, electrical engineering and textile design/manufacturing. Summer camps for recruiting underrepresented students by introducing undergrad and graduate student projects will be pursued

POR.DRECONTENT:
Passive RF components represent the largest footprint in wireless communication systems. With the dramatic growth in spectrum utilization, there is strong interest to employ reconfigurable RF front-ends aimed at reducing size and complexity of the communication device. This project focused on novel fabrication and reconfiguration techniques specifically tailored towards advancement of body wearable textile and low-profile electronics. Embroidery accuracy for body wearable textiles was significantly enhanced to provide feature resolutions down to 0.1mm, viz. comparable to state-of-the-art printed circuit boards (PCBs). This accomplishment paved the way for electronic textiles targeting all types of RF passives (e.g. antennas, filters, miniaturized components).

Reconfiguration was accomplished using metalized plates repositioned within microfluidics channels placed across the textile's surface. Fabrication procedures were concurrently developed that employed low-loss materials and minimized channel wall thicknesses to enhance reconfiguration speed and frequency tuning range. In one reconfiguration method, reconfiguration was shown to achieve wideband frequency tuning across a 2:1 bandwidth. High power handling (15W) was also demonstrated. In a second example, the plates were used as capacitive switches to realize frequency reconfiguration. In a third example, the metalized plates were used to reconfigure a 30GHz Ka-band patch antenna that served as the focal plane of a microwave lens to achieve beam-steering while avoiding RF phase shifters or switches.

Alternatives to phase change materials (PCM) were also investigated/developed using high-quality Vanadium Oxide (VO2) thin films. The latter films were experimentally developed and tested to shown switching between metal and dielectric at about 40 deg C. The applicability of this technique was demonstrated for a reconfigurable terahertz filter and a frequency selective surface.

The research findings of this project have led to the publication of 10 articles in premier journals and 21 conference papers. Hardware demonstrations of wearable antennas, microfluidically reconfigurable antennas and terahertz filters provided confidence for using the proposed methods in practical wireless communication and sensing systems. Further the demonstrations showed that the proposed techniques were not limited to conventional wireless communication spectrum (<6GHz) but extended well into the mm-wave and THz bands. The grant partially supported 4 Ph.D. students. These students acquired key skills in antenna and RF circuits modeling, microfabrication, hardware assembly, textile electronics, and experimental experience in RF components/antennas. In addition to the publications and conference presentations, the results of the project were disseminated in multiple keynote speeches and invited talks. The students involved in the project received several awards for recognition of their work, including an IEEE Antennas and Propagation Society (APS) Doctoral Fellowship, IEEE APS Symposium 2016 Student Paper Honorable Mention, and a Student Paper Finalist recognition at the International Workshop on Antenna Technology (iWAT) 2016
